title: How to Install Appcake on your iPhone or iPad: Easy Download Guide

steps.title: Open the Cydia app on your iPhone or iPad.
steps.content: Open the Cydia app on your iPhone or iPad. The application may take a few moments to load if there are a lot of updates. This method requires a jailbroken iPhone or iPad with Cydia installed. Check out How to Jailbreak an iPhone to learn how to jailbreak, or see the Installing Without Jailbreaking method if you prefer not to jailbreak. The advantage of using AppCake on a jailbroken device is that it won't randomly stop working because of Apple revoking its certificates.

steps.title: Tap Sources.
steps.content: Tap Sources . A list of package sources will appear.

steps.title: Tap Add.
steps.content: Tap Add . A dialog box will appear.

steps.title: Enter the URL of the official AppCake source and tap Add Source.
steps.content: Enter the URL of the official AppCake source and tap Add Source . The URL is https://Cydia.iPhoneCake.com . [1] X Research source A warning will appear, telling you that pirated software might be available through AppCake.

steps.title: Tap Add Anyway if you want to use AppCake.
steps.content: Tap Add Anyway if you want to use AppCake. After a few moments, a new source called AppCake will appear at the top of the Cydia source list. You may have to tap Return to Cydia to get back to the source list.

steps.title: Tap the AppCake source.
steps.content: Tap the AppCake source. It's under the "Individual Sources" header.

steps.title: Tap All Packages.
steps.content: Tap All Packages . A list of apps on AppCake's Cydia source will appear.

steps.title: Tap AppCake.
steps.content: Tap AppCake . It should be at the top of the list. Information about the package, including the AppCake version number, will appear.

steps.title: Tap Install at the top-right corner.
steps.content: Tap Install at the top-right corner. A confirmation message will appear.

steps.title: Tap Confirm.
steps.content: Tap Confirm . AppCake will now install on your iPhone or iPad.#Tap Restart Springboard when prompted. AppCake will now appear on your home screen. Tap its blue-and-white star icon to start using the app.

steps.title: Go to http://www.iphonecake.com in Safari.
steps.content: Go to http://www.iphonecake.com in Safari. A pop-up message will appear, letting you know that you can still install AppCake if your iPhone isn't jailbroken. Installing without jailbreaking generally lets you do all of the same things as if you were jailbroken. But if you choose not to jailbreak, AppCake may stop working for periods of time due to Apple's tendency to revoke its enterprise certificates (common with any alternative app store). If Apple has revoked AppCake's certificate, it can take weeks or longer to get a new certificate. If you don't want to jailbreak and can't use AppCake because the certificate is revoked, AppCake's developers recommend their paid app called iPASTORE . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tap OK on the pop-up.
steps.content: Tap OK on the pop-up. Now you'll see the AppCake website.

steps.title: Tap INSTALL APPCAKE.
steps.content: Tap INSTALL APPCAKE . It's the green button below the large star icon. A pop-up message will appear, asking if you want to install AppCake.

steps.title: Tap Install on the pop-up.
steps.content: Tap Install on the pop-up. AppCake will now install in the background. Don't proceed until the app is finished downloading. You can check on the download by swiping left to the App Library, tapping the search bar at the top, and searching for AppCake. If you see AppCake's blue-and-white star icon next to the app, the download is complete. If it's showing a timer over the icon and it's grayed out, wait for the icon to turn into a blue-and-white star and then move forward. If AppCake's icon is white with lines instead of blue-and-white, tap the icon—if you see an error that says "Unable to Install AppCake – Please try again later," it might be because AppCake has not yet been updated to work with your version of iOS. It also may be because Apple revoked their certificate. Either way, delete the non-working app and wait a few days/a few weeks, and try again. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Tap TRUST CERTIFICATE on the AppCake page in Safari.
steps.content: Tap TRUST CERTIFICATE on the AppCake page in Safari. Another pop-up will appear, asking if you want to download a configuration profile.

steps.title: Tap Allow to start the download.
steps.content: Tap Allow to start the download. Once the profile is downloaded, Safari will redirect you to the Profiles and Device Management screen.

steps.title: Tap the option under "ENTERPRISE APP" and select Trust (the publisher's name).
steps.content: Tap the option under "ENTERPRISE APP" and select Trust (the publisher's name) . The name of the developer may appear differently depending on what's on the certificate. A confirmation screen will appear.

steps.title: Tap Trust.
steps.content: Tap Trust . Now that the certificate's in place, it's time to verify your iPhone with AppCake.

steps.title: Open AppCake and tap Verify.
steps.content: Open AppCake and tap Verify . This will prompt you to download another profile, which will be used to verify your iPhone.

steps.title: Tap Allow.
steps.content: Tap Allow . When the profile is downloaded, tap Close to close the pop-up window.

steps.title: Open the Settings app and tap Profile Downloaded.
steps.content: Open the Settings app and tap Profile Downloaded . It should appear at the top of the Settings menu. You'll be taken to a page that lets you install the profile. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Install and verify your passcode.
steps.content: Tap Install and verify your passcode. Once verified, a confirmation window will appear at the bottom.

steps.title: Tap Install to confirm.
steps.content: Tap Install to confirm. This installs the profile and prompts you to re-open AppCake.

steps.title: Tap Open.
steps.content: Tap Open . AppCake will reopen and display the latest applications.
